questions.audioText: Hey, I'm so excited about this vintage film club idea, but I have no clue how to actually make it official with the university. You mentioned you started a club before, right?
choices: Yes, I did! It's actually not as complicated as it seems. The first step is to check the student activities website for the club registration requirements.
Yeah, but that was for a completely different type of organization. University clubs have totally different requirements that I wouldn't know anything about.
Yes, I did! Once you get approved, you'll need to plan your first screening event and decide on membership fees for the semester.
Actually, I was hoping you could help me figure that out too! I've been thinking about starting a photography club but don't know the requirements either.
Yes, I did! The film selection process is really important. You'll want to start by researching which vintage films have the best educational value for students.

questions.audioText: Okay, what kind of requirements are we talking about?
choices: That's a great question! I remember having the same concerns when I was thinking about starting my club. The vintage film idea sounds really interesting and unique for campus.
Well, you should probably check with the film department first to see if they already have something similar. Then you'll need to find a classroom that's available for regular meetings.
I'm not really sure about all the details either. Maybe we should both go to the student activities office together and ask them what we need to do to get started.
You'll need to register for at least twelve credit hours, meet with an academic advisor, and submit your course selection form before the deadline. The registration portal opens next week.
You'll need at least five founding members, a faculty advisor, and a written constitution that outlines the club's purpose and meeting structure. You'll also need to submit a formal application.

questions.audioText: Five members shouldn't be hard to find - I know a few film enthusiasts already. But how do I find a faculty advisor?
choices: I'd recommend checking with the career services office or academic advisors. They usually know which professors are available and can connect you with someone who has the right qualifications for mentoring.

You'll want to make sure you have your constitution written first. Most departments require that before they'll consider your application. The student activities office can provide you with a template to follow.
That's great that you already have some people in mind! Once you get your five members confirmed, you can schedule your first official meeting and start planning your film screening events.

I'd suggest reaching out to professors in the film studies or English departments. Most are happy to help if the club aligns with their interests. You just need them to sign off on being your advisor.
The application deadline is usually at the beginning of each semester, so you'll want to get everything submitted early. Make sure all your paperwork is complete before the student activities review.

questions.audioText: That makes sense. What about the constitution? That sounds pretty formal.
choices: It depends on your department's requirements. You'll need to check with your academic advisor about course prerequisites, graduation requirements, and how it fits your major. Each program has different standards and approval processes.

It's simpler than it sounds. You just need to outline your mission, meeting frequency, officer roles, and membership requirements. The student activities office has templates you can use as a starting point.

Right, that's important for getting approved. But first you should focus on recruiting those five members and getting your faculty advisor confirmed. Once you have those pieces, the paperwork becomes much easier to handle.
I'm not really sure about that part either. Maybe we should both look into what other clubs have done? I think there might be examples online somewhere that we could check out together.

That's actually the hardest part. You'll need to research other film clubs, conduct surveys about student interest, and present detailed budget projections. The application process can take several months to complete.

questions.audioText: This is really helpful! How long does the whole approval process usually take?
choices: You'll still need to find those five founding members first, and don't forget about getting a faculty advisor from film studies or English departments before submitting anything official.
Once you submit everything, it typically takes about four to six weeks for approval. Then you'll need to resubmit your constitution and find additional faculty sponsors.
I think it usually takes about two to three weeks once I submit everything. Then I can start booking meeting rooms and accessing funding opportunities for my events.
Once you submit everything, it typically takes about two to three weeks for approval. Then you can start scheduling study sessions and accessing library resources for research projects.
Once you submit everything, it typically takes about two to three weeks for approval. Then you can start booking meeting rooms and accessing funding opportunities for events and equipment.

The friend explains the steps, the requirements, and how long approval usually takes.

choices: It's mainly social situations - I'm having conflicts with my roommate, friend drama, and I feel like I can't handle the interpersonal relationships here.

questions.audioText: That sounds overwhelming. The good news is there are several strategies that can help. First, let's talk about time management. Are you currently using any kind of planning system or schedule?

questions.audioText: That approach can actually increase stress. I'd recommend using a planner or digital calendar to break down large tasks into smaller, manageable steps. Also, prioritizing sleep is crucial - aim for 7-8 hours per night and try to maintain a consistent sleep schedule.
choices: That's really helpful advice. Do you think I should also consider changing my major to something less demanding?

questions.audioText: Absolutely. Deep breathing exercises and short meditation sessions can be very effective. Even just 5-10 minutes a day can make a difference. We also offer stress management workshops here at the center that teach relaxation techniques.
choices: Yes, I think I should probably sign up for those workshops sometime next semester.

Great! Do you think we could schedule another meeting to discuss my course selection?

questions.SummaryExample: A writing center tutor assists a student who brings a draft of their history paper and wants help improving their thesis statement and organization. questions.audioText: I really think the narrator in this story is completely unreliable. The way they describe events just doesn't add up.
choices: That's an interesting point about character development. I think the author uses symbolism really effectively throughout the story to show the protagonist's internal conflict and growth.
You make a good argument there. I hadn't really thought about it that way before. Maybe we should look at some more examples from the text.
I agree completely. The inconsistencies in their storytelling really make you question what actually happened. That scene in chapter three is a perfect example of this.
I disagree. I think the narrator is actually being honest about their perspective, even if it's limited. Look at this passage where they admit they don't understand everything.
I see what you mean about unreliable narration. But I think we should also consider the historical context when the author was writing this particular story.

questions.audioText: But that's exactly my point! They contradict themselves multiple times throughout the chapter. How can we trust anything they say?
choices: You're absolutely right about that. I hadn't considered how those inconsistencies could undermine the narrator's credibility throughout the entire story.
Those psychological studies might be relevant here. The research could be showing us how trauma affects people - it's not always perfectly documented.
Those contradictions might be intentional though. The author could be showing us how memory works - it's not always perfectly consistent.
I think we've both made good points today. Maybe we should ask the professor what they think about these different interpretations.
Those contradictions are definitely there though. The narrator could be confused about what happened - memory isn't always perfectly reliable anyway.

questions.audioText: Hmm, I hadn't thought about it that way. But what about when the narrator claims to remember conversations from when they were three years old?
choices: That's a good observation. Maybe we should focus on the statistical significance though. The sample size might be too small to draw reliable conclusions.
That's an excellent point, class. Let me add that to our discussion notes. Both perspectives show sophisticated critical thinking about textual analysis.
You're absolutely right about that contradiction. I think we should probably start looking at some specific examples from the text to support our arguments.
That's a fair point. Maybe the reliability isn't black and white though. They could be reliable about emotions and unreliable about specific details.
That's a fair point about the methodology. Maybe the researcher's bias isn't completely objective though. They could be influenced by their theoretical framework.

questions.audioText: You know what, that actually makes sense. The emotional truth feels consistent even when the facts seem questionable.
choices: Exactly! And looking at it that way, both of our interpretations work. The narrator can be both honest and unreliable depending on what aspect we're focusing on.
Right! And this same principle applies to character development too. The protagonist can be both sympathetic and flawed depending on which scenes we're analyzing.
I still think you're missing the key evidence though. The narrator's contradictions are too frequent to be intentional, and that undermines the emotional authenticity you're talking about.
Exactly! And using that framework, both of our thesis statements are defensible. The narrator can be trustworthy about feelings and questionable about factual details.
That's an excellent observation from both of you. This kind of nuanced thinking about textual interpretation is exactly what I hoped to see in today's discussion.

questions.audioText: I think you're right. This is actually a much richer reading than either of our original positions.
choices: I'm glad we pushed each other on this. It's interesting how the text can support multiple valid interpretations when we really dig into the evidence.
I still think my original interpretation was correct though. The narrator's contradictions really do make them unreliable throughout the entire story.

questions.audioText: Hello! Please, come in and have a seat. I understand you're interested in learning more about our political science program?
choices: Yes, thank you for meeting with me. I'm currently a political science major, but I've been considering switching to environmental studies. I wanted to learn more about the research opportunities and internship programs available.
Of course! I'm glad you're interested in our program. Let me tell you about our core curriculum requirements and the various career paths our graduates typically pursue in government and policy work.

Yes, thank you for meeting with me. I'm currently an economics major, but I've been considering switching to political science. I wanted to learn more about the curriculum and what career paths it might open up.

Yes, thank you for meeting with me. I'm currently an economics major, but I've been considering switching to business administration. I wanted to learn more about the internship requirements and study abroad opportunities.
That sounds perfect. I really appreciate all the information you've shared about the program requirements. This has definitely helped me make my decision about whether to switch majors or not.

questions.audioText: That's great that you're exploring your options. Political science is a versatile field. What specifically drew you away from economics and toward political science?
choices: Well, I've been struggling with my calculus requirements and found myself more drawn to literature and creative writing. I really enjoyed my composition class last semester.
I've always been interested in government and politics. Political science seems like it would give me better preparation for law school than my current major.
Well, I've found myself more interested in policy-making and government processes than economic theory. I really enjoyed my introductory government class last semester.
That's a great question to consider. Many students find political science offers more diverse career paths than economics. You should think about your long-term goals carefully.
Well, I've been worried about my GPA and graduation timeline. I'm not sure if switching majors this late will affect my financial aid eligibility next year.

questions.audioText: Excellent! Our curriculum covers areas like comparative politics, international relations, public policy, and political theory. We also have strong internship programs with local government offices and nonprofit organizations.
choices: That's great to know. I think the internship programs will definitely help me make my final decision.
Yes, we also offer great research opportunities with faculty members and have strong connections with international organizations.
That's exactly what I was hoping to hear. How competitive is the application process for the graduate program?
That sounds really interesting. How different would the coursework be from what I'm used to in economics?
That sounds really helpful. How different would the lab requirements be from what I'm used to in chemistry?

questions.audioText: You'll find less mathematical modeling and more analytical writing and critical thinking about political systems. Your economics background would actually be valuable for our public policy track, since economic principles often inform policy decisions.
choices: That makes sense. How many internship hours would I need to complete for the public policy track requirements?
I appreciate that. Do you think my economics coursework would transfer over if I decide to switch majors?
That's reassuring. What about career opportunities after graduation? I'm worried about job prospects.
That's a great question. Many of our graduates go into government, consulting, or law school for further study.
Yes, I think the mathematical modeling in economics helped me understand policy analysis better than most students.

questions.audioText: Political science graduates go into many fields - government agencies, law school, journalism, campaign management, nonprofit work, and even business. The analytical and communication skills you develop are highly transferable.
choices: That's really helpful information about the different career paths available.
You should definitely consider taking some political science electives first.
What kind of research opportunities are available for undergraduate students here?
How competitive is admission to law school from this program?
Would switching majors at this point delay my graduation significantly?

questions.audioText: It depends on how many credits transfer over. I'd recommend meeting with our academic advisor to map out a degree plan. You might be able to graduate on time if you take summer courses or if some of your economics electives count toward our requirements.
choices: That's really interesting about the internship programs. Could you tell me more about the comparative politics and international relations courses?
I understand about the credit transfers. Do you think my economics background would help me succeed in those political science courses?
Absolutely! I'd be happy to help you map out a degree plan. Let me check my calendar for available meeting times.
That makes sense about the summer courses. What about switching to a business major instead? Would those requirements be easier to fulfill?
This has been really helpful. Could you put me in touch with that advisor? I think I'd like to explore this option further.

questions.SummaryExample: An economics major meets with a political science professor to explore switching majors to political science. They explain that they’re more interested in government, policy-making, and preparation for law school than in economic theory. The professor describes the political science curriculum, how it emphasizes analytical writing and critical thinking rather than heavy math, and outlines possible careers. They also explain that many economics credits might transfer and suggest meeting an advisor to check graduation timing, which the student wants to pursue further.

questions.SummaryExample: At a university career fair, a computer science student approaches a recruiter from a company they’ve been following. The recruiter asks about the student’s background, looks at their resume, and explains the company’s 10-week summer internship program. They talk about the qualifications needed—strong programming, problem solving, and communication skills—and how to apply. The recruiter gives the student a business card and encourages them to apply online and mention that they met at the fair, leaving the student feeling excited and informed.

questions.SummaryExample: A student emails the professor of a required Policy Analysis Methods course because the class is full and missing it would delay graduation. The professor asks about the student’s year, confirms they’re a junior who needs the course for a senior capstone, and checks that they’ve completed the prerequisites. Seeing their situation is urgent and their background is solid, the professor offers to add them on a waitlist, asks them to attend the first week and email their details, and is confident they’ll get a spot, which reassures the student.

questions.SummaryExample: In a lab, a student notices their lab partner seems upset and learns the partner is frustrated by a poor quiz grade despite studying hard. The supportive student listens, validates their feelings, and suggests visiting the professor during office hours. They also remind their partner that one quiz doesn’t define their abilities and compliment their strong lab skills. Together they decide to focus on the current experiment so the partner’s bad mood doesn’t affect their work, and the partner feels encouraged and ready to continue.

questions.SummaryExample: A student working in a campus chemistry lab asks to speak with the lab supervisor about safety concerns. They have noticed that some students don’t follow safety procedures, such as not wearing goggles when handling acids and not disposing of chemical waste properly, especially during times with less supervision. The supervisor takes the concerns seriously, plans more frequent safety reminders and increased monitoring, and schedules a mandatory safety refresher. The student agrees to keep reminding peers and reporting issues and feels heard and supported.

questions.audioText: Thank you for joining us today. As our student representative, we'd like to hear your thoughts on the proposed policy regarding AI tools in academic work. What's the general student sentiment?
choices: Thank you for having me. Based on my personal experience with AI tools, I think they're really helpful for research and writing. I use them regularly for my coursework and haven't had any issues with academic integrity so far.

Thank you for having me. From the feedback I've collected, students are generally supportive of the new plagiarism detection software. They feel it will help maintain academic standards and ensure fair grading across all courses.

Thank you for having me. From what I've observed in my classes, professors have varying approaches to technology use. Some embrace digital tools while others prefer traditional methods, creating inconsistency in academic expectations.

Thank you for having me. I've been researching this topic extensively for my thesis project. The literature shows mixed results about AI implementation in educational settings, particularly regarding student learning outcomes and engagement.

Thank you for having me. From what I've gathered through surveys and discussions, students have mixed feelings. Many appreciate AI as a learning tool, but they're concerned about where to draw the line between assistance and academic dishonesty.

questions.audioText: That's a fair point. What specific concerns have students raised about the current proposal?
choices: Well, from our committee's perspective, we think students need better education about these tools. We should implement mandatory workshops about responsible AI use before allowing any exceptions. The training component is essential for success.

The biggest concern is timing. Students feel rushed with the current semester schedule and want more flexibility with assignment deadlines. For instance, some courses have overlapping due dates that create unnecessary stress. The timeline needs adjustment.

Students generally support the initiative and think it's moving in the right direction. Most people I've talked to are optimistic about the changes and believe this will benefit everyone. The response has been positive.

The main challenge is accessibility. Students want equal access to tutoring resources and office hours. For example, some professors are available during class times only, which conflicts with schedules. The availability needs improvement.

The main issue is clarity. Students want explicit guidelines about what's acceptable. For example, is using AI for brainstorming ideas different from having it write entire paragraphs? The policy needs to be more specific.

questions.audioText: I see. And what about the proposed penalties for violations? How do students feel about those?
choices: Honestly, many students think the penalties are too harsh for first-time offenses. They'd prefer a warning system with mandatory education about proper AI use before moving to more serious consequences.

The penalties seem reasonable to most students. They understand that academic integrity violations need serious consequences, and the proposed structure appears to balance fairness with maintaining educational standards effectively.

Actually, students are still confused about which AI tools are acceptable for different assignments. They need more specific examples of what constitutes appropriate versus inappropriate use in various academic contexts.

From our committee's perspective, we believe these penalties provide appropriate consequences while maintaining academic standards. The graduated approach should effectively deter violations while being fair to students overall.

Students generally support having clear consequences, but they're more concerned about the appeals process. They want to ensure there's adequate opportunity to contest decisions if they disagree with violation determinations.

questions.audioText: That's interesting feedback. What suggestions do students have for implementation?
choices: Students want the policy document to include specific examples of acceptable versus unacceptable AI use. The current language is too vague and leaves too much room for interpretation.
Students are generally supportive of AI guidelines but worry about fairness. They want to make sure the policy doesn't disadvantage students who lack access to technology or resources.

We should probably schedule committee meetings with department heads to ensure faculty understand their responsibilities. Consistent enforcement will require administrative coordination and clear communication protocols.

Students are requesting workshops or training sessions to understand the policy better. They also want professors to be consistent in how they apply these rules across different departments and courses.
Students think the committee should reconsider the penalties since they seem too severe for minor violations. A graduated approach would be much more fair and educational.

questions.audioText: Those are valuable suggestions. Do students see any benefits to having clear AI policies in place?
choices: Absolutely. Many students actually want these guidelines because it creates a level playing field. They don't want to be disadvantaged by not using AI when others might be using it inappropriately.
Definitely. Students want to know exactly what's expected of them. The current uncertainty makes them hesitant to use any AI tools, even for legitimate brainstorming or research purposes.
Students appreciate having clearer guidelines, but they're still concerned about how different professors might interpret the same rules. Consistency remains the biggest challenge we're facing.
Yes, we believe these policies will help maintain academic standards. The committee should focus on creating consistent guidelines that faculty can easily understand and apply.
Well, students are still divided on the enforcement mechanisms. They want to make sure professors receive adequate training before implementing any new policies across departments.

questions.audioText: Thank you for this comprehensive feedback. Would you be willing to work with us on revising the policy draft to address these student concerns?
choices: I appreciate your willingness to collaborate. We'll make sure to incorporate student feedback and schedule follow-up meetings to finalize the policy details.
Thank you for considering our input. I think these discussions have been really productive and I'm glad we could reach a consensus on the policy.
That sounds great. I can help organize those training workshops and work with professors to ensure consistent implementation across all departments.
I'd be happy to participate. I think having clear guidelines will really help students understand what's expected of them regarding AI use.
I'd be happy to help. I think involving students in the revision process will lead to a policy that's both effective and fair for everyone.

questions.SummaryExample: A student representative speaks to a university committee about a proposed policy on AI tools in academic work. They explain that students see both benefits and risks: AI can be a helpful learning aid, but there’s confusion about what counts as acceptable use and concern about harsh penalties for first offenses. Students want clearer examples, consistent enforcement across classes, educational responses before severe punishment, and training or workshops. The committee appreciates the feedback and invites the student to help revise the policy to make it fairer and clearer.

The researcher explains that some items may have more than one reasonable answer and that what matters is the participant’s reasoning, not strictly “right” or “wrong” responses. They clarify that time limits are guidelines, encourage thoughtful responses, and explain the memory recall section should include as many details as possible. They request an accommodation to use a laptop for note-taking and offer documentation from the disability services office. The professor explains concerns about laptops distracting others, but recognizes this is a different situation and suggests the student sit in the front row so the screen isn’t visible to classmates. They agree that the student will bring the documentation next class so the laptop accommodation can be made official.

They recommend contacting the library’s media services department, mentioning that it’s an educational student event with discussion afterward, so the club can follow the proper procedure.

questions.audioText: Hi there, come on in. What can I do for you today?

Hi Professor Chen. I'm Sarah, a junior biology major. I'm really interested in your genetics research and was hoping to learn about research opportunities in your lab.

questions.audioText: That's great to hear! I'm always looking for motivated students. What specifically interests you about genetics research?
choices: Well, I think students should definitely get involved in research early. Gene expression is such an important topic that more undergraduates need to understand these days.

I've always been fascinated by environmental science and conservation biology since my freshman year. Your work on ecosystem dynamics caught my attention in particular.

questions.audioText: Excellent! We're currently working on several projects involving chromatin remodeling and its effects on gene expression. Have you had any research experience before?
choices: I've been working with several undergraduate students on molecular biology projects and they've all shown great enthusiasm for learning research methods.
I haven't had formal research experience yet, but I've done well in my lab courses and I'm eager to learn proper research techniques.
That sounds really interesting! I'd love to hear more about how chromatin remodeling affects gene expression in your current projects.
Yes, I've been teaching genetics concepts to other students and I think my explanations of chromatin remodeling have been really helpful for them.
Well, I've completed most of my major requirements and I'm planning to take advanced genetics and biochemistry courses next semester.

questions.audioText: That's perfectly fine - everyone starts somewhere. Most of our undergraduate researchers begin by learning basic lab techniques like PCR, gel electrophoresis, and cell culture. Are you comfortable with those kinds of procedures?
choices: Yes, I've worked with those methodologies in my literature courses and feel prepared. How much reading and writing is typically involved in your research?
I've heard about those techniques but haven't had much hands-on practice yet. Are there training sessions available for students who need more background preparation?
Yes, I've completed those assignments in my courses and did well on them. What kind of statistical software do you typically use for data analysis?
Yes, I've done those in my classes and feel confident with them. How much time commitment are you typically looking for from undergraduate researchers?
Those are definitely important foundational skills for any biology student. I'd recommend starting with our introductory workshop series before jumping into advanced research projects.

questions.audioText: I usually ask for about 8-10 hours per week, which can be flexible around your class schedule. We also encourage students to stay for at least two semesters to really get meaningful experience. Would that work for you?
choices: That's great! I think the molecular biology course will really help me prepare for graduate applications.
Yes, I'd love to learn more about your chemistry research and what lab techniques you use.
That sounds reasonable. I'm sure other students in my biology classes would be interested too.
Thank you so much for your time, Professor Chen. I'll definitely consider everything you've told me today.
That sounds perfect! What would be the next steps if I wanted to join your lab?

questions.SummaryExample: A junior biology major visits Professor Chen’s office hours to ask about joining their genetics research lab. The student explains that they’re especially interested in gene expression, regulation, and the professor’s work on epigenetics, and although they haven’t had formal research experience, they’ve done well in lab courses and are eager to learn. The professor describes current projects on chromatin remodeling, explains that undergraduates usually start with basic techniques like PCR and gel electrophoresis, and says the typical expectation is 8–10 hours per week over at least two semesters. The student is enthusiastic and asks about next steps to join the lab.

The professor agrees to help, emphasizes how important the personal statement is, and advises customizing it for each program and highlighting research experience. When the student asks if they should mention their work in the professor’s lab, the professor strongly encourages it as concrete evidence of commitment. The student thanks them and promises to send a draft soon for detailed feedback.

questions.audioText: Sure, let me pull up the rubric. For that question, we were looking for three main components: a clear definition of democratic institutions, specific examples, and analysis of their role in governance. Most students struggled with providing concrete examples.
choices: I see what you mean. I should have focused more on the analysis section rather than just the definition part.

choices: Got it. So I needed to show how the statistical methods work in practice, not just define the mathematical concepts?

questions.audioText: Exactly. For full points, you would need to discuss things like checks and balances, representation, or judicial review. The analysis component was worth the most points on this question.

choices: That makes perfect sense, thank you. I really appreciate you taking the time to review my essay question.

Great! I'll make sure to schedule another appointment next week to go over the reading materials together.
Perfect, thank you so much for the feedback. This really helps me understand what to focus on for my presentation.

questions.SummaryExample: A student goes to the teaching assistant’s office hours to ask about the grading on one essay question from their graded midterm exam. The TA explains that the rubric required a clear definition of democratic institutions, specific examples, and deeper analysis of how those institutions function in democratic governance. The student had named correct examples like Congress and the Supreme Court but didn’t fully explain their democratic role. After the TA clarifies that analysis of concepts like checks and balances and representation was worth the most points, they recommend a textbook chapter and additional articles to strengthen the student’s understanding for the final exam.

choices: Professor, I need your help. I'm trying to decide between taking Cultural Anthropology or Ethnographic Methods and I'm not sure which one I should take.
Professor, I'm thinking about getting a specialization in computer science. I just wanted to know what the requirements are and what classes I would need to take.
Professor, I'm a second year and I'm trying to decide between two fields, world history and anthropology. I wanted to get your opinion on the pros and cons of studying each of them.
Hi, Professor. I'm a second year and I'm planning on choosing my field of study soon. I wanted to know if you could give me some advice on what classes to take.
Professor, I wanted to ask you about something. I'm considering applying for a teaching assistantship and I wanted to know what the requirements are.

questions.audioText: Sure, I'm happy to answer your questions! The requirements for the specialization are six courses, including an Intro to Computer Science course and three advanced courses.
choices: Yeah, I took that class last semester. It was pretty interesting!
That sounds manageable. I'm just worried about getting my work in on time with that part-time job.
Okay, that's helpful. What about the other assignments? I would love to still submit them.
Okay, that sounds doable. I'll talk to my project group about it.
Okay, that doesn't seem too bad. What advanced courses would you recommend?

questions.audioText: It depends on your interests. Are you interested in software engineering, artificial intelligence, or maybe something like human-computer interaction?
choices: I'm not really sure yet. What are the differences between the three of them?
Not yet, I just wanted to get more information about it first.
Yeah, my advisor suggested a few but I'm still not sure.
What do you recommend? I've taken a couple of classes like that before.
Not really, I just find the subject really interesting in general.

questions.audioText: Well, software engineering focuses on designing and building software systems while artificial intelligence studies algorithms that can learn and make predictions. And human-computer interaction examines how people use technology and how to design interfaces.
choices: Well, I'm interested in all of them! I don't really know which one to choose!
Okay, that's helpful. I'm mostly interested in trying to develop that research topic further.
Yeah, those both sound like they could be interesting. Are they offered next semester?
Perfect! Do you have any suggestions on which classes would satisfy this requirement?
Okay, what if I'm interested in a specific topic that's not covered in that class?

questions.audioText: Why don't you take one introductory course on each of them next semester and then decide which one you want to focus on after that? That way you can get a taste of each area before you commit to anything.
choices: Sounds good to us! Thanks for suggesting it.
Okay, those would be very helpful! What can I do to help?
Oh, I see. That explains my grade. Thank you, Professor!
Yeah, that's a good idea. Maybe I'll try that next time.
That sounds like a good idea! Thank you, Professor!

questions.SummaryExample: A second-year student asks their professor about getting a specialization in computer science. The professor explains the course requirements, describes different areas like software engineering, AI and HCI, and suggests trying intro courses in each before choosing a focus.
